net.alevel.asteroids.game.physics.SATJava

Class SATJava

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.alevel.asteroids.game.physics.pipeline.FunctionPipeline
      • net.alevel.asteroids.game.physics.SATJava.SATJava
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<PipelineableFunction>, PipelineableFunction

    public class SATJava
extends FunctionPipeline
implements PipelineableFunction
    A simple implementation of the 'Separating Axis Theorem (SAT)' algorithm. This is a common method of collision detection in games. Firstly, it calculates a normal vector for each triangle. These will be used as the axis that each object.

    The projection is done like this:
    let 'A' be The world coordinate of the vertex to project
    let 'n' the axis to project onto. The axis is treated as a 3D line going through the origin. n is the direction of this line
    let 'B' the point on the line where the line AB is perpendicular to the line 'n'
    then B = lambda * n
    AB = B - A
    dot(AB, n) = 0
    n.x * (n.x * lambda - A.x) + n.y * (n.y * lambda - A.y) + n.z * (n.z * lambda - A.z) = 0
    pow(n.x, 2) * lambda - A.x * n.x + pow(n.y, 2) * lambda - A.y * n.y + pow(n.z, 2) * lambda - A.z * n.z = 0
    lambda * (pow(n.x, 2) + pow(n.y, 2) + pow(n.z, 2)) = A.x * n.x + A.y * n.y + A.z * n.z
    lambda = dot(A, n) / pow(length(n), 2)
